title: 104_s1273
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Investment Act of 1995" and includes a provision for a tax credit on interest paid on education loans. The "Higher Education Investment Act of 1995" allows individuals a tax credit of 20% on interest paid on qualified education loans, up to a maximum of $500 ($1,000 for multiple individuals). There is an income limitation for the credit, with a threshold of $40,000 ($60,000 for joint filers). The tax credit allowable under the "Higher Education Investment Act of 1995" is subject to reduction based on excess amounts and modified adjusted gross income. The $40,000 and $60,000 income thresholds for the credit will be adjusted for inflation after 1996. The tax credit under the "Higher Education Investment Act of 1995" will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, with rounding rules applied. No credit will be allowed to individuals if certain conditions are not met. A tax credit for interest paid on qualified education loans is allowed for the first 60 months, excluding refinancings. The credit is only available if no deduction under section 151 is allowed to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. A tax credit for interest paid on qualified education loans is allowed for the first 60 months, excluding refinancings, if no deduction under section 151 is allowed to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. The credit is available if the taxpayer or their spouse is allowed a deduction under section 151 and the individual is at least a half-time student. A qualified education loan is defined as indebtedness incurred to pay qualified higher education expenses for the taxpayer, their spouse, or a dependent. The term 'qualified education loan' refers to indebtedness used to pay for education expenses, excluding loans owed to a related person. 'Qualified higher education expenses' include the cost of attendance for the taxpayer. The Act defines 'eligible educational institution' as a place offering internship or residency programs leading to a degree, certificate, or postgraduate training. A 'half-time student' is someone who would be considered a student if enrolled part-time. The term 'dependent' is also defined within the Act. The Act defines 'dependent' as per section 152 and includes special rules such as denying double benefits and requiring married couples to file joint returns. Marital status is determined according to section 7703. There is a reporting requirement under subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 6050Q mandates returns for education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. Any person engaged in a trade or business who receives $600 or more in interest on a qualified education loan in a calendar year must file a return with specific details as prescribed by the Secretary. SEC. 6050Q mandates returns for education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals, including governmental units. Special rules apply to governmental units, where the trade or business requirement is disregarded, and returns are made by designated officers or employees. Statements must be furnished to individuals for whom information is required. Every person required to make a return under subsection (a) must provide a written statement to each individual showing the name, address, and aggregate amount of interest received. The statement must be given by January 31 of the following year. The term 'qualified education loan' is defined as per section 23(e)(1) unless specified otherwise by the Secretary. In the case of interest received by one person on behalf of another, only the first recipient is required to make the return under subsection (a). Clerical amendments have been made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 23 defines a qualified education loan. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include returns relating to education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. The amendments apply to loans incurred before or after the enactment date, with interest payments due after December 31, 1995.
